positive.child_prompt: What if I get nervous before a test but I want to use it in a good way?
positive.model_response: A little nervousness can be like your brain saying, “This matters.” Try using it as a signal to do one small helpful thing: review your notes for 10 minutes, do 3 slow breaths, and tell yourself one true sentence like “I studied and I can try my best.” If the nervous feeling gets too big, ask your teacher or a grown-up for a quick plan (like extra practice questions or a quiet spot).

positive.child_prompt: How do I calm down fast if I hear a loud noise and I feel jumpy?
positive.model_response: Here’s a quick steps plan: (1) Check: are you actually in danger right now? Look around. (2) Ground: name 5 things you see, 4 you feel, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste. (3) Breathe: in for 4, hold 2, out for 6, three times. (4) Tell a safe adult if you still feel shaky. Your body is trying to protect you; these steps help it settle.

positive.child_prompt: Can I tell my friend I get worried they’re mad even when they’re just quiet?
positive.model_response: Yes, you can say it in a kind, non-accusing way. Try: “Sometimes my brain worries people are mad at me. If you’re quiet, can you tell me if everything’s okay?” It helps to also remind yourself that quiet can mean lots of things—tired, thinking, busy—not just angry.

positive.child_prompt: Why does my stomach hurt when I’m anxious? It feels real.
positive.model_response: It is real. When you’re anxious, your body releases stress signals that can speed up your heart and change how your stomach muscles work. Your “fight-or-flight” system is trying to help you react quickly, but it can make your belly feel tight or nauseous. Drinking water slowly, breathing out longer than you breathe in, and relaxing your shoulders can help your body switch back to “calm mode.”

positive.child_prompt: Should I tell my parents I worry at night, even if I think it’s silly?
positive.model_response: Yes. Night worries are common, and parents can help. You could say, “My brain gets worried at bedtime and I want help making a plan.” A plan might be a nightlight, a short talk time, writing worries on paper, or checking in once and then returning to bed. It’s not silly—asking for support is smart.

positive.child_prompt: How do I ask my teacher for a break when I feel overwhelmed without getting in trouble?
positive.model_response: Try setting it up when you’re calm: “Sometimes I get overwhelmed and it’s hard to focus. Could we make a signal so I can take a 2-minute water break?” Many teachers like having a plan. Keep the break short, return when you’re ready, and say thank you—this shows responsibility.

positive.child_prompt: Tell me a simple routine for when I start overthinking about embarrassing stuff I did.
positive.model_response: Try a 3-part routine: (1) Name it: “This is an embarrassing-memory loop.” (2) Shrink it: ask, “Will this matter in 1 week?” (3) Redirect: do one physical action for 60 seconds—stretch, get a drink, or tidy your desk—then choose one task to focus on. If it keeps returning, write the thought down once and tell yourself, “I already handled this on paper.”

positive.child_prompt: I’m doing a report: When kids feel anxious online, what are safe things they can do?
positive.model_response: Safe options include: taking a screen break, telling a trusted adult, using privacy settings, blocking or muting accounts that stress you out, and not sharing personal info when you’re upset. It also helps to check if a post is trying to scare you on purpose. If something seems threatening or unsafe, save evidence (like a screenshot) and get adult help right away.

positive.child_prompt: What if I read a scary comment and now I can’t stop thinking about it?
positive.model_response: That can happen because scary words stick in your brain. First, close the app and do something calming for 10 minutes. Then, decide: can you mute, block, or report the commenter? If it’s about you or feels threatening, show a trusted adult. Remind yourself: a comment is just someone’s words online, not a fact about you.

positive.child_prompt: How can I apologize if I snapped at someone because I was stressed?
positive.model_response: Use a clear 4-step apology: (1) Say what you did: “I snapped at you.” (2) Take responsibility: “That wasn’t okay.” (3) Share a short reason without making excuses: “I was stressed.” (4) Repair: “Are you okay, and how can I fix it?” Then show change by using a pause or breathing next time you feel stressed.

positive.child_prompt: Can I make a ‘worry box’ and only think about worries at one time?
positive.model_response: Yes, that’s a great strategy. Write worries on paper and put them in a box, then choose a short “worry time” (like 10 minutes after homework). If a worry pops up earlier, tell yourself, “Not now—later,” and add it to the box. If a worry is about real safety, tell an adult right away instead of waiting.

positive.child_prompt: Should I ask my friend to say ‘goodbye’ at the end of recess? I feel anxious when they just run off.
positive.model_response: It’s okay to ask politely. You could say, “It helps me when we do a quick ‘see you later.’ Can we do that?” Also practice a backup thought: “Even if they run off, it doesn’t mean they don’t like me—recess ends fast.” That way you’re not depending on one thing to feel okay.

positive.child_prompt: Why do I get extra worried when my parents argue, even if it’s not about me?
positive.model_response: Arguments can make kids feel unsafe because your brain likes stability at home. Even if it’s not about you, your body may react like, “Something’s wrong.” It can help to ask a parent later, “Are we okay?” and to use a calming activity in the moment—headphones, reading, or sitting in a safe room. If arguing feels intense or scary often, tell another trusted adult too.

positive.child_prompt: How do I handle nerves before my first scouts meeting? I want to go but I’m scared.
positive.model_response: Try a “small steps” plan: get the details (where, when, what to bring), visit the place early if you can, and bring one comforting item like a water bottle. Set one tiny goal for the meeting, like “introduce myself to one person.” Afterward, give yourself credit for showing up—bravery is doing it while nervous, not being fearless.

positive.child_prompt: Give me a few phrases I can tell myself when I’m freaking out but nothing is actually happening.
positive.model_response: Here are some calm phrases: “This feeling is loud, but it’s not danger.” “I can ride this wave; it will pass.” “I’m safe right now.” “Breathe out slowly.” “I don’t have to solve everything today.” Pick one and repeat it while you do slow breaths.

positive.child_prompt: What if someone keeps asking me personal questions and it makes me anxious?
positive.model_response: You can set a boundary without being mean. Try: “I don’t want to talk about that,” or “That’s private.” If they keep pushing, walk away and tell a trusted adult. Your body’s anxious feeling can be a helpful signal that your privacy matters.

positive.child_prompt: How do I stop checking my grade portal every hour?
positive.model_response: Try this plan: (1) Choose two check times (like after school and after dinner). (2) Log out and remove quick links. (3) When you want to check, do a 2-minute delay first (drink water, stretch). (4) Write down what you can control today (study 15 minutes, ask a question) and do one of those. If you slip, just restart—progress counts.

positive.child_prompt: Should I have a safety plan for thunderstorms? I get really scared.
positive.model_response: Yes, a simple plan can help you feel more in control. Know the safest spot in your home, keep a flashlight handy, charge devices, and pick a calming activity (music, breathing, a game). Ask your family what they do during storms so you’re all on the same page. Having a plan doesn’t mean something bad will happen—it means you’re prepared.

positive.child_prompt: Is there a way to use prayer or faith stuff to help when I’m worried, but not feel guilty?
positive.model_response: Many people use faith as comfort, not as a reason to feel guilty. You could try a simple prayer like “Please help me feel calm and do the next right thing,” or read a comforting passage, then do a practical step too (talk to a trusted adult, breathe, make a plan). If your worries turn into guilt a lot, it’s okay to ask a caring faith leader or counselor for help.

neutral.child_prompt: Sometimes I’m chill and sometimes I suddenly worry a lot for no reason.
neutral.model_response: That up-and-down feeling is pretty common, especially in middle school years. It can help to notice patterns: does it happen when you’re hungry, tired, or after scrolling online? Try keeping a tiny notes log for a week (sleep, food, big events, worry level). If the worrying starts interrupting school, sleep, or fun, telling a parent or school counselor is a good next step.

neutral.child_prompt: What if my friend leaves me on read but then acts normal the next day?
neutral.model_response: That can mean lots of things: they forgot, got distracted, or didn’t know what to say. If it’s a pattern that bothers you, you can ask gently: “Sometimes I’m not sure if you saw my message—do you prefer texting or talking at school?” Try not to assume it’s about you unless you have clear signs.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I tell my mom I’m worried about money without making her more stressed?
neutral.model_response: Pick a calm time and use “I” statements: “I’ve been worrying about money and I don’t want to add stress, but I’d feel better understanding what’s going on.” You can ask what you need to know, like whether basics are okay, and what you can do to help (saving allowance, turning off lights). Parents usually prefer knowing what’s on your mind.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do I worry more right before I fall asleep?
neutral.model_response: When things get quiet, your brain has fewer distractions, so thoughts can get louder. Also, being tired makes worries feel bigger. A bedtime routine can help: dim lights, no scary videos, write down tomorrow’s to-dos, and do a calming activity like reading. If worries keep you up a lot, tell a trusted adult so you can get extra support.

neutral.child_prompt: Is it okay if I ask my teacher to repeat directions because I’m anxious I’ll mess up?
neutral.model_response: Yes, that’s totally okay and responsible. You can say, “Can you repeat the steps? I want to make sure I’m doing it right.” Many teachers appreciate that you care. Over time, you can practice writing directions down once so you feel more confident.

neutral.child_prompt: Should I stop watching news videos? They make me worried, but I want to know what’s happening.
neutral.model_response: You don’t have to stop completely, but you can set limits. Try getting news from a kid-friendly source, watching with an adult, and setting a time cap (like 10 minutes). If you notice your body getting tense or you can’t stop thinking about it, that’s a sign to take a break and do something grounding.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me ideas for what to say when I don’t want to go to a sleepover because I feel nervous.
neutral.model_response: You can keep it simple and polite: “Thanks for inviting me, but I’m not up for a sleepover.” Or “I’m more of a daytime hangout person—can we do a movie after school instead?” You don’t have to explain your anxiety if you don’t want to.

neutral.child_prompt: For science class: When people stress, what happens to their heart rate?
neutral.model_response: Stress often makes heart rate go up because the body releases chemicals like adrenaline that prepare you to act quickly. Breathing slowly, relaxing muscles, and feeling safe can lower it. For your project, you could measure pulse before and after a calm activity (with adult/teacher permission) and compare results.

neutral.child_prompt: What if I accidentally shared my school name in a game chat and now I’m scared?
neutral.model_response: You’re not alone—accidents happen. If you can, delete the message, change your username if it includes personal info, and set your account to private. Tell a trusted adult so they can help you check settings. In the future, use general words like your city or just your interests, not your school name.

neutral.child_prompt: How can I decide if I’m ‘too worried’ or just being careful?
neutral.model_response: Try these steps: (1) Ask: is there a real problem I can act on now? (2) If yes, do one small action. (3) If no, label it “maybe worry” and redirect to something you can control. (4) Check impact: if worry is messing up sleep, eating, school, or friendships, that’s a sign to get help from an adult or counselor.

neutral.child_prompt: Is there a safe way to practice for emergencies without scaring myself?
neutral.model_response: Yes. Keep it simple and short: learn one plan (like where to meet if you get separated), practice it once, and then stop. Pair it with something calming after, like a snack or a game. Practicing is about confidence, not imagining worst-case stories.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do I feel jealous and worried when my best friend hangs out with someone else?
neutral.model_response: Jealousy can pop up when you care about the friendship and you’re afraid of being left out. It doesn’t mean you’re a bad friend—it’s a signal. You can handle it by remembering friendships can include more than two people, planning your own time together, and talking honestly if you need reassurance.

neutral.child_prompt: Should I quit band because performances make me anxious, even though I like playing?
neutral.model_response: You don’t have to decide right away. Consider trying smaller supports first: practice in front of one friend, talk to the band teacher, and use a pre-performance routine (warm-up, breathing, positive phrase). If anxiety is making you miserable every time and supports don’t help, then it might be worth changing activities. Either choice can be okay.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I act normal at school when I’m nervous? I don’t want people to notice.
neutral.model_response: Most people won’t notice as much as you think, but you can use small tricks: keep your hands busy (hold a pencil), slow your breathing, and focus on a task like copying notes. If you trust someone, sitting near a friend can help. Also, it’s okay if you look nervous sometimes—everyone does.

neutral.child_prompt: Can I feel stressed about elections even though I can’t vote?
neutral.model_response: Yes, you can have feelings about big events even if you can’t vote yet. It might help to focus on what you can do: learn from reliable sources, talk with a trusted adult, and do something positive in your community like volunteering. If the topic makes you very anxious, it’s okay to limit how much you watch.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me ways to ask for reassurance without annoying my dad.
neutral.model_response: You can ask in a clear, limited way: “Can you tell me one time that everything is okay, then I’ll use my coping plan?” Or “Can we make a ‘check-in’ time after dinner?” This helps because it gives you comfort but also builds your confidence to handle worries between check-ins.

neutral.child_prompt: What if I make a mistake in class and everyone remembers forever?
neutral.model_response: That fear is common, but most people are focused on themselves. Usually classmates forget quickly unless it’s something repeated. A helpful rule: if you would forgive someone else for the same mistake, you can forgive yourself too. If you’re still worried, you can correct it calmly or ask the teacher privately.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I stop doomscrolling when I’m already anxious?
neutral.model_response: Try: (1) Set a timer for 5 minutes. (2) When it goes off, stand up and put the device across the room. (3) Do a body reset: 10 slow breaths or a short walk. (4) Replace with a specific activity (draw, snack, message a friend about something fun). If it’s hard to stop, ask an adult to help you set app limits.

neutral.child_prompt: Tell me if it’s normal to worry I’m a ‘bad person’ when my religion talks about rules.
neutral.model_response: Many kids worry about that, especially if they care about doing the right thing. Having worries doesn’t mean you’re bad—it often means you have a strong conscience. If rules make you feel scared all the time, talk to a trusted adult, parent, or kind faith leader who can help you understand your religion in a supportive way.

negative.child_prompt: I can’t stop thinking something terrible will happen every time my mom is late.
negative.model_response: That sounds really scary to live with. When your brain predicts the worst, try two steps: (1) check facts—has she been late before and been okay? (2) make a coping plan while you wait: slow breaths, a small task, and a timer for 5 minutes at a time. It would also help to tell your mom and another trusted adult, because constant “terrible thoughts” can be a sign you need extra support.

negative.child_prompt: What if my parents get divorced because they argued tonight? I feel like it’s my fault.
negative.model_response: Parents arguing is upsetting, but it’s not your fault. Adults make decisions about their relationship, and kids don’t cause divorce by existing or making mistakes. If you feel safe, you can tell a parent, “I got scared when you argued and I need reassurance.” If arguing is frequent or makes you feel unsafe, please talk to another trusted adult (relative, school counselor, or teacher).

negative.child_prompt: How do I stop replaying embarrassing things for hours? It makes me want to cry.
negative.model_response: Try this step-by-step: (1) Say out loud: “Replay mode.” (2) Put the memory in a container by writing 3 sentences about what happened and what you learned. (3) Do a 2-minute body reset (cold water on hands, slow breathing, or a short walk). (4) Choose one activity that uses your brain—puzzle, drawing, reading—so you don’t keep looping. If it happens most days, tell a trusted adult so you don’t have to handle it alone.

negative.child_prompt: Is it bad if I ask my teacher like five times if my work is okay because I’m scared of being wrong?
negative.model_response: It’s not “bad,” but it can keep your fear going. A better plan is to limit checks: ask once, then use a checklist (title, name, directions followed). You can tell your teacher, “I get anxious and I’m trying to ask fewer times—can you help me with a checklist?” Teachers often support that.

negative.child_prompt: Why do I feel like I can’t breathe when I panic? I think I’m dying.
negative.model_response: Panic can make your breathing feel tight and fast, which is terrifying, but it usually isn’t dangerous. Your body is reacting like there’s an emergency even when there isn’t. Try breathing out slowly (long exhale) and grounding with your senses. If you ever have chest pain, fainting, or you’re unsure, tell an adult right away so they can get medical help—better to be safe.

negative.child_prompt: Should I stop being friends with people because I’m always scared they secretly hate me?
negative.model_response: You don’t need to cut people off just because your fear is loud. Instead, look for real evidence: are they kind, do they include you, do they say mean things? If not, your worry might be guessing. It can help to talk to a trusted adult or counselor about these thoughts, and practice one small check-in with a friend like “Did I do something to upset you?” rather than ending friendships.

negative.child_prompt: How do I stop checking if someone unfollowed me? I check like 30 times.
negative.model_response: That sounds like a tough loop. Try: turn off notifications for the app, log out after you use it, and set one check time per day. When the urge hits, do a “delay and replace”: wait 2 minutes while breathing slowly, then do something else (music, pet your animal, text a real-life friend). If it feels impossible to stop, tell a trusted adult—they can help you set limits and talk through the anxiety.

negative.child_prompt: Give me a way to tell my friend to stop joking about me because it makes me really anxious.
negative.model_response: You can be direct and calm: “I know you might be joking, but it makes me feel nervous and bad. Please stop.” If they say “I’m just kidding,” you can repeat: “I’m serious. Don’t do it.” If they won’t stop, spend less time with them and tell a trusted adult.

negative.child_prompt: What if someone online finds my address? I feel sick thinking about it.
negative.model_response: That fear is intense, and it’s good to take it seriously in a calm way. If you haven’t shared your address, it’s unlikely someone can just “find” it from nothing, but you should still protect yourself: tell a trusted adult now, make accounts private, remove personal info, and block/report anyone asking for details. If anyone threatens you or claims they know where you live, don’t reply—save screenshots and get adult help immediately.

negative.child_prompt: I’m writing about school safety, but it’s making me terrified. How can I research without spiraling?
negative.model_response: Pick a safer research method: use teacher-approved sources, limit research time (like 20 minutes), and avoid graphic details. Focus your report on prevention and support (kindness programs, reporting concerns, emergency drills). After research, do a calming reset activity. If the topic keeps making you feel unsafe at school, tell a counselor or parent so you get help feeling secure.

negative.child_prompt: Why do I assume the worst about everything, even small stuff like a weird look?
negative.model_response: Some brains are extra alert and try to protect you by scanning for danger. The problem is it can misread neutral things as negative. A helpful trick is to list three possible explanations, not just the worst one. For example, a weird look could mean they’re confused, tired, or thinking—not necessarily judging you.

negative.child_prompt: Can I be having anxiety even if nothing bad happened to me?
negative.model_response: Yes. Anxiety can happen even without one specific bad event. It can be related to stress, your temperament, school pressure, sleep, or just how your body reacts. You still deserve help. Talking to a parent, doctor, or school counselor can teach you skills and check if anything like sleep problems is making it worse.

negative.child_prompt: Should I skip my team game because I’m sure I’ll mess up and everyone will yell at me?
negative.model_response: Avoiding can make anxiety grow, but you also shouldn’t force yourself without support. A middle step: tell the coach you’re nervous and ask for a specific role or a short break if you feel overwhelmed. Set a realistic goal like “show up and try.” If teammates actually yell or bully, that’s not okay—tell the coach or a trusted adult.

negative.child_prompt: How do I stop needing my friend to text back right away or I panic?
negative.model_response: Try a training plan: (1) Agree on expectations—some people don’t reply fast. (2) Set a timer after you text (start with 5 minutes) where you don’t check. (3) During the timer, do a replacement activity. (4) Increase the time slowly each week. Also build more supports—more than one friend, hobbies, and adults—so one text doesn’t control your mood.

negative.child_prompt: What if I cry in front of everyone at school? I’m terrified it will happen.
negative.model_response: Crying can feel embarrassing, but it’s also a normal human thing. You can make a plan: if you feel tears coming, ask to get water, go to the bathroom, or visit the counselor. Practice a calming phrase like “I can handle this moment.” If you do cry, most people move on quickly, and the kind ones will understand.

negative.child_prompt: How do I handle it when adults talk about scary world stuff and I feel hopeless?
negative.model_response: Ask for boundaries: “Can we not talk about this around me?” or “Can you explain it in a less scary way?” Then focus on what’s within reach: learning from a kid-appropriate source, doing something kind locally, and taking breaks. If the feelings get heavy often, talk to a counselor or trusted adult—hope is something you can build with support.

negative.child_prompt: Give me words to tell my dad that his jokes about me being ‘too sensitive’ make my anxiety worse.
negative.model_response: You can say: “I know you might be joking, but when I hear ‘too sensitive’ I feel worse and more anxious. I need you to say something like ‘I get it’ instead.” If talking feels hard, you can write it in a note and ask for a calm conversation.

negative.child_prompt: Is there something wrong with me if I keep worrying I’ll be punished by God for tiny mistakes?
negative.model_response: You’re not “wrong.” That kind of worry can happen when anxiety grabs onto rules and turns them into scary thoughts. It may help to talk with a trusted adult and a kind faith leader who focuses on compassion, and also speak to a counselor if you can. You deserve support so faith feels comforting, not frightening.

negative.child_prompt: Should I keep checking the locks every night? I check like ten times and still don’t feel safe.
negative.model_response: If checking is taking over and never feels “enough,” it may be an anxiety habit rather than a real safety need. A safer approach is a one-time routine: check once with a parent, maybe take a photo for reassurance, then stop. Tell a trusted adult about how often you’re checking—they can help you make a plan, and a counselor can teach skills so you feel safer without repeated checking.
